channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Wait, what? A RAT caught and ate a BAT? And there's video! What does it portend?
item.description: Scientists filmed bats to see how they communicate while swarming. They found a surprise: In urban settings, rats attack bats. What are the implications for bats ... and virus spread to humans?
item.content:encoded:
Scientists filmed bats to see how they communicate while swarming. They found a surprise: In urban settings, rats attack bats. What are the implications for bats ... and virus spread to humans?

(Image credit: Gloza-Rausch et al, Global Ecology and Conservation)
item.dc:creator: Bec Roldan

item.title: Immigration agents have new technology to identify and track people
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security is adopting powerful new tools to monitor noncitizens. Privacy advocates are worried they erode privacy rights for immigrants and Americans alike.
item.content:encoded:
The Department of Homeland Security is adopting powerful new tools to monitor noncitizens. Privacy advocates are worried they erode privacy rights for immigrants and Americans alike.

(Image credit: Madison Swart /Hans Lucas via AFP)
item.dc:creator: Jude Joffe-Block

item.title: What to know about the 5 hostages whose remains are still in Gaza
item.description: In the most recent release, Hamas returned the remains of an Israeli man who died while fighting Hamas in the Oct. 7, 2023 attack. He was identified as Lior Rudaeff, who was 61 when he was killed.
item.content:encoded:
In the most recent release, Hamas returned the remains of an Israeli man who died while fighting Hamas in the Oct. 7, 2023 attack. He was identified as Lior Rudaeff, who was 61 when he was killed.

(Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: UPS and FedEx grounding MD-11 planes following deadly Kentucky crash
item.description: UPS and FedEx will ground their fleets of McDonnell Douglas MD-11 planes "out of an abundance of caution" following a deadly crash at the UPS global aviation hub in Kentucky.
item.content:encoded:
UPS and FedEx will ground their fleets of McDonnell Douglas MD-11 planes "out of an abundance of caution" following a deadly crash at the UPS global aviation hub in Kentucky.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Supreme Court temporarily blocks full SNAP benefits even as they'd started to go out
item.description: The high court decision allows a lower court time to consider a more lasting pause. The Trump administration is appealing an order to fully fund November food aid for millions of people.
item.content:encoded:
The high court decision allows a lower court time to consider a more lasting pause. The Trump administration is appealing an order to fully fund November food aid for millions of people.

(Image credit: Nam Y. Huh)
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Ludden

item.title: James Watson, who co-discovered the structure of DNA, has died at age 97
item.description: James Watson, who co-discovered the structure of DNA has died at age 97. He was a scientific superstar until he made racist remarks that made him an outcast.
item.content:encoded:
James Watson, who co-discovered the structure of DNA has died at age 97. He was a scientific superstar until he made racist remarks that made him an outcast.

(Image credit: J. Conrad Williams, Jr./Newsday)
item.dc:creator: Nell Greenfieldboyce

item.title: As millions of Americans struggle with SNAP lapses, food banks are swamped with demand
item.description: At one food pantry in Boston, the spike in demand means there's now a two-week wait for some to receive food, stressing needy families as well as pantry staff.
item.content:encoded:
At one food pantry in Boston, the spike in demand means there's now a two-week wait for some to receive food, stressing needy families as well as pantry staff.

(Image credit: Tovia Smith)
item.dc:creator: Tovia Smith

item.title: Traveling soon? What the FAA's flight reductions could mean for you
item.description: The FAA is cutting 10% of air traffic at 40 of the nation's busiest airports, canceling hundreds of flights and creating uncertainty for many more passengers. Here's what to do if you're one of them.
item.content:encoded:
The FAA is cutting 10% of air traffic at 40 of the nation's busiest airports, canceling hundreds of flights and creating uncertainty for many more passengers. Here's what to do if you're one of them.

(Image credit: Timothy A. Clary)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: OpenAI's new web browser has ChatGPT baked in. That's raising some privacy questions
item.description: The Atlas browser can act as your "agent" online, doing tasks like shopping or booking tickets. But that gives it access to a lot of personal information.
item.content:encoded: The Atlas browser can act as your "agent" online, doing tasks like shopping or booking tickets. But that gives it access to a lot of personal information.
item.dc:creator: John Ruwitch

item.title: The FAA's air traffic reductions are taking effect. Here's what to know
item.description: Airlines are canceling hundreds of flights to comply with the FAA's order. But there are still questions about the plan, which the agency says will keep the skies safe during the government shutdown.
item.content:encoded:
Airlines are canceling hundreds of flights to comply with the FAA's order. But there are still questions about the plan, which the agency says will keep the skies safe during the government shutdown.

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose
